metadata.description: Comprehensive Question Bank for Media Ideology Detection

dimensions.name: Economic System
dimensions.description: Evaluates economic ideology from communism (-10) to radical laissez-faire capitalism (+10)

dimensions.name: Social Values
dimensions.description: Measures stance from strong progressive liberalism (-10) to strong traditional conservatism (+10)

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss government ownership of industries, nationalization, or public vs. private enterprise?

left_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for complete government ownership of all major industries (manufacturing, energy, transportation, banking) with elimination of private enterprise?

references.source: Marx, K. & Engels, F. (1848). The Communist Manifesto
references.concept: Abolition of private property and centralized means of production

references.source: Lenin, V.I. (1917). The State and Revolution
references.concept: State ownership of means of production

left_leaning.question: Does the article support government ownership of key strategic industries (utilities, healthcare, transportation) while allowing limited private enterprise in non-essential sectors?

references.source: Crosland, A. (1956). The Future of Socialism
references.concept: Mixed economy with significant public ownership
Social ownership of commanding heights of economy

left_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for public options or government-run alternatives in essential services (healthcare, education, banking) alongside private providers?

references.source: Piketty, T. (2014). Capital in the Twenty-First Century

left_leaning.question: Does the article support strategic government investment and public-private partnerships to address market failures while maintaining predominantly private ownership?

references.concept: Government as market shaper and risk-taker

references.source: Stiglitz, J. (2012). The Price of Inequality

right_leaning.question: Does the article support privatization of some government services while maintaining public oversight and regulation?

references.source: Osborne, D. & Gaebler, T. (1992). Reinventing Government

right_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for significant privatization of government services and industries, arguing private sector is inherently more efficient?

references.source: Smith, A. (1776). The Wealth of Nations
Buchanan, J. & Tullock, G. (1962). The Calculus of Consent
references.concept: Public choice theory and government inefficiency

right_leaning.question: Does the article argue for near-complete privatization, including essential services like prisons, military functions, or social security?

references.source: Nozick, R. (1974). Anarchy, State, and Utopia
Rothbard, M. (1973). For a New Liberty

right_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for complete elimination of government ownership and provision of all services, including defense and courts, in favor of private alternatives?

references.source: Rothbard, M. (1982). The Ethics of Liberty
Hoppe, H.H. (2001). Democracy: The God That Failed

centrism.question: Does the article present a balanced view, supporting neither significant nationalization nor extensive privatization, favoring mixed economy pragmatism?

references.source: Keynes, J.M. (1936). The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss taxation policies, tax rates, wealth taxes, or tax reform?

left_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for extreme wealth redistribution through confiscatory taxation (90%+ marginal rates) or complete elimination of private wealth accumulation?

references.source: Marx, K. (1875). Critique of the Gotha Programme
references.concept: From each according to ability, to each according to needs

left_leaning.question: Does the article support highly progressive taxation with wealth taxes, significantly higher corporate taxes, and closing of tax loopholes for the wealthy?

references.source: Saez, E. & Zucman, G. (2019). The Triumph of Injustice
references.concept: Wealth taxation and progressive tax reform

left_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for moderately higher taxes on high incomes and corporations to fund expanded social programs?
Does the article support maintaining current progressive taxation with modest increases to fund specific programs or reduce deficits?

references.source: Krugman, P. (2012). End This Depression Now!

right_leaning.question: Does the article support modest tax cuts or simplification while maintaining progressive structure?

references.source: Mankiw, N.G. (2010). Spreading the Wealth Around

right_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for significant tax cuts, flatter tax rates, and reduced corporate taxation to stimulate growth?
Does the article support flat tax or consumption-based taxation, arguing progressive taxes distort incentives and punish success?

references.source: Hall, R. & Rabushka, A. (1985). The Flat Tax
Hayek, F.A. (1960). The Constitution of Liberty

right_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for elimination of income tax entirely, or argue that taxation itself is a form of theft?

references.source: Nozick, R. (1974). Anarchy, State, and Utopia
Rothbard, M. (1982). The Ethics of Liberty

centrism.question: Does the article present a balanced view on taxation, neither advocating for significant increases nor cuts, focusing on efficiency and fairness?

references.source: Mirrlees, J. (2011). Tax by Design: The Mirrlees Review

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss labor rights, unions, worker protections, minimum wage, or employment regulations?

left_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for worker ownership of all means of production, mandatory worker councils, or elimination of the employer-employee relationship?
Does the article strongly support mandatory union membership, sector-wide collective bargaining, and significant expansion of worker rights?

references.source: Freeman, R. & Medoff, J. (1984). What Do Unions Do?
references.concept: Union benefits for workers and economy

left_leaning.question: Does the article support strengthening unions, raising minimum wage significantly ($15+/hour or living wage), and expanding worker protections?

references.source: Card, D. & Krueger, A. (1995). Myth and Measurement

left_leaning.question: Does the article support moderate increases in minimum wage and maintaining current labor protections?

references.source: Dube, A. (2019). Minimum Wages and the Distribution of Family Incomes

right_leaning.question: Does the article support right-to-work laws or modest reforms to reduce union power while maintaining basic worker protections?

references.source: Epstein, R. (1983). A Common Law for Labor Relations

right_leaning.question: Does the article argue for significant reduction in union power, opposing minimum wage increases as harmful to employment?

references.source: Neumark, D. & Wascher, W. (2008). Minimum Wages

right_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for elimination of minimum wage and most labor regulations, arguing markets should set wages?

references.source: Hayek, F.A. (1960). The Constitution of Liberty

right_leaning.question: Does the article argue for complete deregulation of labor markets, including elimination of all wage floors, overtime rules, and workplace safety regulations?

references.source: Rothbard, M. (1962). Man, Economy, and State

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views on labor, supporting both worker rights and business flexibility?

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss corporate regulation, antitrust policy, consumer protection, or business oversight?

left_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for breaking up all large corporations, eliminating corporate personhood, or nationalizing dominant firms?
Does the article support aggressive antitrust enforcement, breaking up tech giants, and heavy regulation of corporate behavior?

references.source: Wu, T. (2018). The Curse of Bigness

left_leaning.question: Does the article support strengthened consumer protections, environmental regulations, and corporate accountability measures?
Does the article support maintaining current regulatory frameworks with targeted enhancements for emerging issues?

references.source: Sunstein, C. (2013). Simpler: The Future of Government

right_leaning.question: Does the article support modest regulatory reform to reduce compliance burden while maintaining core protections?

references.source: Breyer, S. (1982). Regulation and Its Reform

right_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for significant deregulation, arguing regulations harm innovation and economic growth?

references.source: Stigler, G. (1971). The Theory of Economic Regulation

right_leaning.question: Does the article argue for near-elimination of corporate regulation, suggesting market forces and litigation are sufficient?

references.source: Friedman, M. & Friedman, R. (1980). Free to Choose

right_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for complete elimination of all business regulations, including safety, environmental, and consumer protections?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views on regulation, supporting evidence-based approach to both protection and growth?

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss international trade, tariffs, free trade agreements, or globalization?

left_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for complete state control of international trade, rejection of all free trade agreements, and autarkic economic policy?

references.source: List, F. (1841). The National System of Political Economy

left_leaning.question: Does the article support fair trade over free trade, emphasizing strong labor and environmental standards as conditions for trade agreements?

references.source: Stiglitz, J. (2002). Globalization and Its Discontents

left_leaning.question: Does the article support renegotiating trade deals to better protect domestic workers and industries?

references.source: Autor, D. et al. (2016). The China Shock

left_leaning.question: Does the article support free trade in principle but call for stronger safety nets for displaced workers?

right_leaning.question: Does the article support free trade agreements with modest protections for sensitive industries?

references.source: Bhagwati, J. (2004). In Defense of Globalization

right_leaning.question: Does the article strongly advocate for free trade and reduction of tariffs, arguing protectionism harms consumers and growth?

references.source: Smith, A. (1776). The Wealth of Nations
Ricardo, D. (1817). Principles of Political Economy

right_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for unilateral free trade regardless of other countries' policies?
Does the article argue for complete elimination of all trade barriers, tariffs, and government involvement in international commerce?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views on trade, recognizing both benefits and costs of globalization?

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss social welfare programs, safety nets, entitlements, or poverty alleviation?

left_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for universal basic income, guaranteed employment, or comprehensive cradle-to-grave welfare state?

references.source: Van Parijs, P. & Vanderborght, Y. (2017). Basic Income: A Radical Proposal
Esping-Andersen, G. (1990). Three Worlds of Welfare Capitalism

left_leaning.question: Does the article support significant expansion of welfare programs, including extended unemployment benefits, housing assistance, and childcare subsidies?

references.source: Hacker, J. (2006). The Great Risk Shift

left_leaning.question: Does the article support strengthening existing safety net programs and expanding eligibility?

references.source: Moffitt, R. (2015). The Deserving Poor, The Family, and the U.S. Welfare System

left_leaning.question: Does the article support maintaining current welfare programs with modest improvements to effectiveness?

references.source: Haskins, R. & Sawhill, I. (2009). Creating an Opportunity Society

right_leaning.question: Does the article support welfare reform emphasizing work requirements and time limits while maintaining basic safety nets?
Does the article argue for significant reduction in welfare spending, emphasizing personal responsibility and private charity?
Does the article advocate for elimination of most federal welfare programs, shifting responsibility to states, localities, or private organizations?

references.source: Tanner, M. (1996). The End of Welfare

right_leaning.question: Does the article argue for complete elimination of all government welfare programs, relying entirely on voluntary charity?

references.source: Rothbard, M. (1982). The Ethics of Liberty

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views on welfare, supporting safety nets while emphasizing effectiveness and work incentives?

references.source: Blank, R. (1997). It Takes a Nation

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss banking regulation, financial markets, Wall Street, or monetary policy?

left_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for nationalizing banks, eliminating private banking, or complete government control of financial sector?

references.source: Mellor, M. (2010). The Future of Money

left_leaning.question: Does the article support breaking up big banks, reinstating Glass-Steagall, or heavy financial transaction taxes?
Does the article support strengthened consumer financial protections and stricter capital requirements for banks?
Does the article support maintaining post-2008 financial regulations with modest enhancements?

references.source: Barr, M. et al. (2016). Financial Regulation: Law and Policy

right_leaning.question: Does the article support modest rollback of financial regulations to reduce compliance costs while maintaining systemic protections?

references.source: Calomiris, C. & Haber, S. (2014). Fragile by Design

right_leaning.question: Does the article argue for significant deregulation of financial sector, emphasizing market discipline over government oversight?

references.source: Greenspan, A. (2007). The Age of Turbulence

right_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for elimination of most financial regulations, ending deposit insurance, or abolishing the Federal Reserve?

references.source: Selgin, G. (1988). The Theory of Free Banking

right_leaning.question: Does the article argue for complete elimination of all financial regulation, allowing fully free banking and private currency?

references.source: Rothbard, M. (1983). The Mystery of Banking

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views on financial regulation, supporting prudential oversight while encouraging innovation?

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss LGBTQ+ rights, same-sex marriage, gender identity, or related civil rights issues?

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for comprehensive LGBTQ+ rights including marriage equality, adoption rights, anti-discrimination protections, transgender healthcare coverage, and legal gender recognition?

references.source: Human Rights Campaign - Corporate Equality Index

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article strongly support LGBTQ+ rights including marriage equality and anti-discrimination laws, with some debate on specific implementation?

references.concept: Title VII protections for LGBTQ+ workers

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article support basic LGBTQ+ civil rights protections while expressing some reservations about specific policies like gender-affirming care for minors?

references.source: Pew Research Center - Changing Attitudes on Same-Sex Marriage

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article express general support for LGBTQ+ rights but emphasize need to balance with religious liberty concerns?

references.source: Masterpiece Cakeshop v. Colorado Civil Rights Commission (2018)

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article support civil unions or legal protections for same-sex couples while opposing marriage equality?
Does the article oppose same-sex marriage and most LGBTQ+ specific protections, emphasizing traditional marriage and family values?
Does the article strongly oppose LGBTQ+ rights, arguing homosexuality is immoral and should not be legally protected?
Does the article advocate for criminalization of homosexual behavior, conversion therapy, or complete exclusion of LGBTQ+ individuals from civil protections?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views, acknowledging both LGBTQ+ rights and religious/traditional concerns without strong advocacy either way?

references.source: Pew Research Center surveys on LGBTQ+ issues

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss abortion, reproductive rights, family planning, or related policies?

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for unrestricted abortion access at any stage, government funding for abortion, and abortion as a fundamental healthcare right?
Does the article strongly support abortion rights with minimal restrictions, opposing waiting periods, parental notification, and ultrasound requirements?
Does the article support abortion rights generally while accepting some regulations like gestational limits in later pregnancy?
Does the article express support for abortion being legal in early pregnancy with acceptance of some reasonable regulations?

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article support abortion restrictions but allow exceptions for rape, incest, and life of mother?
Does the article oppose most abortions, supporting significant restrictions while allowing only for life of mother?

references.source: Americans United for Life model legislation

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article strongly oppose abortion in all cases except imminent threat to mother's life, framing abortion as morally equivalent to murder?

references.source: National Right to Life Committee positions

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for complete abortion ban with no exceptions, potentially including criminal penalties for providers and patients?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views, acknowledging both pro-choice and pro-life perspectives without strong advocacy?

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss immigration policy, refugee policy, or treatment of immigrants from a social/cultural perspective?

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for open borders, abolishing immigration enforcement agencies, or treating immigration as a human right?

references.source: Carens, J. (2013). The Ethics of Immigration

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article strongly support immigration, pathways to citizenship for undocumented immigrants, and sanctuary city policies?
Does the article support immigration reform that provides legal status for long-term undocumented residents and increases legal immigration?
Does the article support humane treatment of immigrants and modest increases in legal immigration while acknowledging need for border security?

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article support merit-based immigration reform and stricter enforcement while opposing mass deportation?
Does the article advocate for significant reduction in legal immigration, stricter enforcement, and opposition to amnesty programs?
Does the article strongly oppose immigration, supporting mass deportation and dramatic reduction in legal immigration to preserve cultural identity?
Does the article advocate for near-complete halt to immigration, deportation of all undocumented immigrants, and explicitly nativist or ethno-nationalist arguments?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views, supporting both border security and humane treatment of immigrants?

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss climate change, environmental policy, or related regulations?

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for radical transformation of economy to address climate change, such as Green New Deal, banning fossil fuels, or climate emergency declarations with wartime mobilization?
Does the article strongly support aggressive climate action including carbon taxes, strict emissions regulations, and rapid transition to renewable energy?
Does the article support meaningful climate action through market mechanisms like cap-and-trade and investment in clean energy?
Does the article acknowledge climate change as a problem requiring action but emphasize gradual, cost-effective approaches?

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article acknowledge climate change but argue for technology-focused solutions over regulation, opposing carbon taxes?
Does the article express skepticism about climate urgency, opposing most climate regulations as economically harmful?
Does the article question climate science consensus, strongly oppose environmental regulations, and prioritize fossil fuel industry?
Does the article deny human-caused climate change entirely, characterize it as a hoax, or advocate for elimination of all environmental protections?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views, acknowledging climate concerns while weighing economic trade-offs?

references.source: Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change Working Group III

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss racial justice, systemic racism, affirmative action, or racial equity policies?

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for reparations, radical restructuring of institutions to eliminate systemic racism, or defunding/abolishing police?

references.source: Coates, T. (2014). The Case for Reparations

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article strongly support anti-racist policies, affirmative action, and acknowledges systemic racism as a major ongoing problem?

references.source: Kendi, I. (2019). How to Be an Antiracist

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article support diversity initiatives, acknowledge historical discrimination, and favor policies to reduce racial disparities?
Does the article support some racial equity measures while emphasizing class-based rather than race-specific solutions?

references.source: Wilson, W.J. (1978). The Declining Significance of Race

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article oppose race-specific policies but support equal opportunity and acknowledge some historical injustices?
Does the article oppose affirmative action and most racial equity policies as discriminatory, emphasizing individual responsibility?

references.source: Students for Fair Admissions v. Harvard (2023)
Sowell, T. (2004). Affirmative Action Around the World

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article deny systemic racism exists, oppose diversity initiatives, and argue racism is primarily a historical rather than current issue?
Does the article promote explicitly racial hierarchy views, defend historical discrimination, or oppose civil rights protections entirely?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views on racial issues, acknowledging both historical injustices and concerns about race-based policies?

references.source: Public opinion polling on racial justice

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss gender equality, feminism, women's rights, or gender-related policies?

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for radical feminist restructuring of society, mandatory gender quotas, or elimination of all gender-based distinctions?

references.source: MacKinnon, C. (1989). Toward a Feminist Theory of the State

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article strongly support feminist policies including paid family leave, pay equity legislation, and addressing systemic gender discrimination?
Does the article support gender equality measures like equal pay laws and anti-harassment policies?
Does the article express support for gender equality while acknowledging some biological or preference-based differences?

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article support equal rights while opposing gender quotas and emphasizing different but complementary roles?
Does the article oppose most feminist policies, argue gender gaps are largely explained by choices, and support traditional gender roles?
Does the article strongly advocate for traditional gender roles as natural and beneficial, opposing workplace equality efforts?
Does the article argue women should be excluded from certain professions, oppose women's suffrage principles, or promote explicit patriarchal ideology?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views on gender, supporting equality while respecting individual choices?

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss gun rights, gun control, Second Amendment issues, or firearm regulations?

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for repealing the Second Amendment, banning all civilian firearms, or mandatory gun confiscation?
Does the article strongly support assault weapons bans, mandatory buybacks, strict licensing requirements, and significant restrictions on gun ownership?
Does the article support enhanced background checks, red flag laws, and moderate restrictions while acknowledging gun rights?
Does the article support some common-sense gun measures like universal background checks while respecting Second Amendment rights?

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article support Second Amendment rights while accepting some regulations like background checks?
Does the article strongly support gun rights, oppose most new gun control measures, and support concealed carry expansion?
Does the article advocate for constitutional carry, oppose virtually all gun regulations, and view gun ownership as essential to freedom?
Does the article argue for elimination of all gun laws, including machine gun bans, and advocate armed resistance to any gun regulation?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views, supporting both gun rights and reasonable safety measures?

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss criminal justice, policing, incarceration, or justice reform?

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for prison abolition, defunding police, or radical transformation of justice system toward restorative/transformative justice?

references.source: Movement for Black Lives defund demands

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article strongly support decarceration, ending cash bail, decriminalizing drugs, and significant police reform?
Does the article support criminal justice reform including reduced sentences, police accountability, and rehabilitation focus?
Does the article support some reform efforts while maintaining support for law enforcement?

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article support law enforcement while acknowledging need for some reforms and accountability?
Does the article strongly support law enforcement, oppose defund movements, and emphasize tough-on-crime policies?
Does the article advocate for increased incarceration, expanded police powers, and oppose most criminal justice reforms?
Does the article advocate for extreme punitive measures, expanding death penalty, or support vigilante justice?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views on criminal justice, supporting both public safety and reform?

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss religious freedom, church-state separation, or role of religion in public life?

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for strict secularism, removing all religious references from public life, or treating religious exemptions as discrimination?
Does the article strongly support church-state separation and argue religious exemptions should not override civil rights laws?

references.source: Americans United for Separation of Church and State

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article support religious freedom while arguing it should be balanced against other civil rights?
Does the article support both religious freedom and secular governance without strong advocacy either way?

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article support religious freedom protections while respecting secular governance?
Does the article strongly support religious freedom exemptions and argue religion has important public role?
Does the article advocate for significant religious influence in public policy and education, including school prayer?
Does the article advocate for theocracy, Christian nationalism, or explicit religious test for public office?

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views on religion and government, supporting both freedom and separation?

preliminary_check.question: Does the article discuss education policy, school choice, curriculum, or higher education?

progressive_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for universal free education through graduate school, eliminating private schools, or complete government control of curriculum?
Does the article strongly support increased education funding, universal pre-K, free community college, and progressive curriculum including diversity education?
Does the article support increased public school funding and oppose school voucher programs?
Does the article support public education while acknowledging need for some reforms?

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article support school choice options including charter schools while maintaining public education?
Does the article strongly support school vouchers, parental rights in curriculum, and reducing federal education role?

references.source: Friedman, M. (1955). The Role of Government in Education

conservative_leaning.question: Does the article advocate for universal school vouchers, eliminating Department of Education, and opposing progressive curriculum elements?
Does the article argue for eliminating public schools entirely in favor of private/homeschool, or advocate religious education only?

references.source: Separation of school and state movement

centrism.question: Does the article present balanced views on education, supporting both public schools and some choice options?

scoring_methodology.description: How to calculate final ideology scores

economic_score_calculation.method: Average scores across all applicable economic topics
economic_score_calculation.notes: Topics scored as NA (not applicable) are excluded from calculation

social_score_calculation.method: Average scores across all applicable social topics
social_score_calculation.notes: Topics scored as NA (not applicable) are excluded from calculation

combined_score.method: Weighted combination of economic and social scores

question_flow.step_1: Apply preliminary check for each topic
question_flow.step_2: If Yes, determine if article leans left or right on topic
question_flow.step_3: Start from most extreme position and work toward center
question_flow.step_4: Score at first Yes answer, or score 0 if all answers are No
